Award.AwardTitle: Sustainability: Promoting Sustainable Decision Making in Informal Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Oregon Museum of Science and Industry (OMSI) will partner with the City of Portland's Office of Sustainable Development, Metro Regional Government, Portland Community College, Verde, and the Coalition for a Livable Future, to create a series of informal science education experiences on the theme of Sustainability. For this project, sustainability is defined in terms of a triple bottom line of economic, social, and environmental needs. The project responds to calls for broad environmental education of the public in response to environmental crises (such as climate change), and specific research suggesting that even museums that do provide information about such issues rarely help their visitors learn to make the comparisons necessary to make more sustainable choices.

For the public audience, the project team will create a 1,500 sq. ft. bilingual (Spanish/English) exhibition to encourage the public to develop skills in making personal choices that affect the sustainability of their community. They will also create 25-40 bilingual cell phone tags that will provide listeners who dial the phone numbers with information, personal perspectives, current STEM research, invitations to contribute ideas or vote on issues, interactive phone-based activities, and links to websites, all in service of helping them make intentional and informed personal decisions on sustainability. The cell phone tags will be located at approximately 100 locations in the Portland area, including predominantly Hispanic neighborhoods, public transit locations, public works, and community projects. The team will also create a bilingual website and will offer quarterly bilingual events at the museum on the topic of sustainable living.

For the professional audience, the team will create a set of tools and indicators for assessing the sustainability of exhibit-development processes, using the triple bottom line of financial, environmental, and social impacts. For example, a Green Exhibit Guide will provide resources and a checklist for exhibit development projects, and will propose field-wide standards analogous to the LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) rating system for green buildings. Regional workshops will engage exhibit developers, designers, fabricators, and administrators in using the tools in their own institutions.

The project will create a coordinated set of resources to inform the public about the science of sustainability and to engage them in making informed choices in their daily lives, both in the museum and beyond. The topic of sustainability is timely and important, and the use of cell phones as a mobile technology linked to web resources and an exhibition constitute an innovative synergy of media to create impacts on a city-wide scale. The project serves underrepresented Hispanic audiences through its creation of bilingual materials, placement of cell phone tags, and community involvement in the development process. Finally, the project advances the ISE field in proposing and broadly disseminating a set of standards for green exhibit design, along with developing resources and tools for assessing sustainability. Created in collaboration with other organizations, this work has the potential to reduce the environmental impact of museums while providing highly visible examples of sustainable practices for visitors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF), the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry (OMSI) project Sustainability: Promoting Sustainable Decision Making in Informal Education focused on creating and testing several innovative means of “promoting sustainable decision making” in the Portland area and in the museum field. Project deliverables were based on three identified needs for museum educators and the public: 1) people need to know how to make more sustainable choices to address societal, economic, and environmental problems; 2) people need to know how to weigh the impacts of their actions to make more sustainable choices; and 3) the museum field needs tools to measure its environmental impact in order to make more sustainable choices.

Based on literature research, front-end evaluation with Portland area families, and input from regional partners, OMSI developed a positive approach to engage regional English- and Spanish-speaking families through the following deliverables:

  • A 1,500-square-foot bilingual (Spanish/English) exhibition designed to engage the public with everyday personal choices that affect the sustainability of their communities.
  • A bilingual outreach campaign that used a variety of “access points” based on physical and electronic media to encourage people to visit the interactive, story-based project website (www.omsi.edu/choices and www.omsi.edu/decisiones).
  • Eight bilingual events at OMSI on various topics related to sustainable living for families.

The Sustainability project also created and distributed resources and training opportunities for museums across North America to: 1) promote sustainable practices for developing, designing, and fabricating exhibits; and 2) develop and test an industry standard for sustainable exhibit design and fabrication. This effort led to the www.exhibitSEED.org website and eight workshops held across the country for exhibit professionals focusing on tools and resources for incorporating sustainable decision-making into the exhibit development process. During the life of the project, exhibit professionals from at least 115 institutions in thirty-three states, Puerto Rico, and Ontario, Canada participated in ExhibitSEED workshops and over thirty institutions have used the Green Exhibit Checklist to evaluate the environmental sustainability of one of their exhibits.

To develop project deliverables with relevance to the regional community, OMSI partnered closely with METRO regional government, the City of Portland’s Bureau of Planning and Sustainability, the Coalition for a Livable Future, Verde, and Portland Community College to develop and implement these sustainability-related initiatives. OMSI also worked with over fifteen additional community organizations to create content and promote the project.

Evaluation of the project indicated that all of the deliverables successfully met their intended goals and impacts, but that some methods for reaching these goals were more successful than others. The Clever Together/Juntos somos ingeniosos exhibition opened at OMSI in 2012. During its eight-year run, we anticipate that the exhibition will reach more than three million visitors. Based on surveys conducted in the exhibition, the summative evaluation found that sustainability is a challenging concept for visitors. Evaluators suggested promoting better understanding of decision-making skills using the three-pillar (social, economic, and environmental) framework. In response to this input, the project team created complementary demonstrations to reinforce key messages of the exhibition.
